div.p: 1. IV. Fishing party, from Newcomb’s Wharf— return to Quincy.

I rose at four— Lighted my lamp and wrote Letters to the Secretary of the Treasury, and to Mr T. Gaillard at Newport— Breakfasted, and rode with Antoine to Newcomb’s wharf, near the Bent’s point Bridge— At half past seven our company were assembled. Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf— George Beale and his Son, Mr M’Alister, Edward Miller, William Smith, my brother and his Sons Isaac, John and Joseph, and my Son George— We embarked in a small Sloop belonging to Quincy, with Hardwick and Josiah Adams junr. upon a fishing party below the Boston Light House— The weather was all day fine— We left the wharf with a light and favourable breeze, and within an hour had run two thirds of the way to the Light-House; but it then fell to a flat calm, and for four hours we barely drifted with the tide—passed the Light about noon, and reaching the first fishing ground not before two— Here one good sized Cod—one Haddock, and one or two other fish were caught; but with some delay, and a fresh breeze springing up the vessel drifted too much for cod-fishing— We twice changed our fishing ground without success, and as at our former party, by three in the afternoon were obliged to make sail homeward— With alternate calms and light heading breezes we reached at the dusk of Evening the wharf from which we had taken our departure, and Mr Daniel Greenleaf took me home— While the vessel was under way, we fished for mackerel, of which I caught about 30. I had taken with me a map of Boston and its vicinity ten miles round, belonging to my brother; and viewed the islands in the bay, between Quincy, and the Light-House— It added very little to my knowledge of the topography of Boston Harbour and Bay. But the map was very imperfect, and I had no pocket compass— I have now within the last eight years been upon five fishing parties below the Boston light— Always favoured with fine weather— Always baffled with calms— A cod, and a mackerel fishing line, I now had, but they were new, ill adjusted and useless— New lines require a thorough soaking in Sea water, before they can be used— A pocket compass, a good telescope, and a Sailors dress are suitable equipments for such a party— We had a very good Chowder— My Son Charles went to Boston this day, and returned this evening.
2. V. Bath—

The tide serving this morning at 8. O’Clock, I bathed with Antoine, and my three nephews immediately after Breakfast—the water was very cold but I swam from wharf to wharf— Heard Dr Foster of Brighton from Matthew 16.17. “And Jesus answered, and said unto him, Blessed art thou, Simon Barjona; for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in Heaven.” And in the afternoon from Hebrews 13.16. “But to do good and to communicate, forget not; for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.” Dr Foster is one of the liberal preachers of the Old School— His discourses are benevolent and moral, but not very impressive—his delivery serious, and without impropriety; but cold— He is about leaving his parish at Brighton where he has been many years settled, but where dissension has been introduced, by more ardent clerical rivals of the Calvinistic creed, who make proselytes by their earnestness and activity, and being instant in Season and out of Season. Dr Foster dined with us— Mr Quincy walked home with me from the afternoon service: and Mrs Quincy and her two daughters gave the Ladies a call— The other visitors came in the Evening— Mr Gay is Consul of the United States at the Islands, now absent upon leave, and came now with his Lady, an English woman from Dedham— Mr Marston came with his Son the Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, and the other young men were introduced to me, by Mr George Whitney. I wrote little this day; the morning having been occupied in reading despatches from A. Gallatin received last night—
3. V. Bath— Boston— Medford— Boston.

My Sons George and Charles came to Boston in the Stage. Asa Beach was an old man of 68. a straggling traveller from Fleming near Auburn in the State of New-York. He came to see me for mere curiosity, and talked about politics and the prison at Auburn. He closed his visit by asking Miss Sparhawk to play a tune for him on the Piano, which she did— The Revd. Mr Osgood had sent me yesterday a Letter enclosing two printed papers—proceedings of a Society formed in London for the civilization of the Indians in Canada— Mr Osgood solicited assistance from me to the funds of this Society, which I declined; observing that the United States considered it a principle of political obligation that the British Government should in no form whatever interfere in the concerns of Indians within the territories of the United States— And I deemed it my duty to pursue that course with regard to the Indians within the British Dominions— I said the objects of the Society, appeared to me to be altogether laudable, and I approved of their plan of civilizing the Indians, by conciliating them to the British Provincial Government and Laws— We were now suffering much inconvenience from having attempted to civilize Indians upon the plan of leaving them when civilized, as Independent Societies, within our Territories, which we were now finding to be utterly impracticable— The only manner of making their civilized state contribute to their own benefit or to ours would be to bring them within the pale of our own Government and Laws; and I was pleased to see this Society formed under the countenance of the British authority, proceeding upon that basis— I added that I had a personal acquaintance of many years standing with the Duke of Sussex, who had presided at the formation of the Society and had great esteem for his character— The Revd. Mr Frere, is one of the Missionaries to our Indians at Mackinaw, in the Michigan Territory. He said he had come out with Mr Osgood, at his request, but having no connection whatever with his purpose— But he said that the plan pursued by him and our missionaries with the Michigan Indians, was founded entirely on the principle of bringing them by civilization, under the government of our Laws— Mr Osgood at the close of our conversation thanked me for the interview, and expressed no dissatisfaction at my determination— I bathed at the creek with my brothersthree Sons and Antoine, and came with him into Boston to the Exchange Hotel. I took a Hack, and paid visits to Governor Lincoln, and Mr James Lloyd. I saw them both, and their Ladies— Mr Lloyd has sold his house, and proposes to pass the winter at Philadelphia, and perhaps partly at Washington. He probably intends a definitive removal from this State to a warmer climate— I told Governor Lincoln, that since seeing him I had received several despatches from Mr Gallatin; and that in one of them incidental notice was taken of the state of the Negotiation relating to the Northeastern boundary. There were several other despatches upon other subjects, and thinking the perusal of them might be interesting to him, I had brought them with me; and I put them into his hands requesting that after reading them he would send them this Evening or to morrow morning to the Exchange Hotel— He said he would and expressed his gratification at this mark of confidence— I returned to the Exchange and immediately went with Antoine to Medford, and dined at Mr P. C. Brooks’s— The party consisted of General S. Van Rensselaer and his daughter, Mr and Mrs Davis, Dr. and Mrs Pendleton, and Miss Bard, all of New-York—a Mrs Blodget of Gibraltar, Mr and Mrs Frothingham, Mr and Mrs Everett, Mr and Mrs P. C. Brooks junr. and Henry Brooks, and my Son Charles— In the Evening, I left Charles at Medford, and returned with Antoine to Boston. At the door of the Exchange Hotel, I found Johnson Hellen and my Son John, just arrived in the Stage from Lebanon, which they left yesterday morning—and my wife there—very well— They came on a bird’s visit; and intend to depart upon their return to-morrow. They could not be accommodated with lodgings at Hamilton’s; the house being full, and went to lodge at Earle’s in Hanover Street— The party at Mr Brooks’s was very pleasant. Mrs Davis was very lively and talkative— Mrs Blodget is wife to a merchant of Gibraltar, in whose compting House, Mr Brooks’s youngest Son Horatio is now placed—
4. V:10. Bath— Neponset dinner— Boston. Medford—

Johnson Hellen and my Son John went this Morning out to Quincy: came back and departed upon their return to Lebanon; intending to go this Evening as far as Worcester— Mr Quincy called on me with a Doctor Lieber, a German who has recently established a swimming school in this City— He had sent me an invitation to come and see it, which he now repeated— I accordingly walked with Mr Quincy to the Avenue, where we found Dr Lieber, and went with him in a boat to the scaffolding which he has erected for his school— It is a floating Platform, in hollow square, with a surface of water within of about an acre; with small rooms at the four corners, for undressing and keeping his furniture at the centre of the three sides of his platform, are stands, four feet high, from which his scholars leap or dive into the water and on the fourth side is a spiral Staircase, perhaps forty feet high, with stands at different elevations, from which the pupils may leap or plunge— There were ten or twelve boys taking lessons while we were there— He says his complete course is of twenty-one lessons, teaching the pupil to swim a full half hour; but many learnt in less— Some in five or six lessons— He has two assistants, and sixty-six pupils. His first lessons are given with a matted belt slung under the arms, and held by a long rope, in the hand of an assistant— At a more advanced Stage he lays aside the belt, and substitutes a long pole, with a rope, floating so near to the swimmer that he can seize it at any moment— The boys there were at different stages of their progress, but none of them had yet learnt to dive well— Most of them jumped in from the low stands one from the stair stand as high as twenty feet— At the Doctors invitation I went in to the bath myself and swam about ten minutes— The Doctor went in at the same time. I then returnd with Mr Quincy to the Exchange Hotel— He left me, and came again with his chaise at one. I rode out with him to Neponset Bridge, and dined with the Directors at the Inn upon the Dorchester side. The company were Mr Quincy, my brother, T GreenleafG W Beale, Mr Wailes, Edward Miller, and James H. Foster. We had a sumptuous dinner and at the dusk of Evening, I returned with Mr Quincy to Boston. I there found at Hamiltons, Miss Selden, and Miss Hanson of Washington, and a Mr Pollard— They had just arrived from Lebanon, which they left on Saturday, the day before John and brought me a Letter from my wife, and one from Abigail to Elizabeth Adams— After a visit of a few minutes to those Ladies, I came out with my Son Charles to Mr P. C. Brooks’s at Medford. I had received an invitation to an Evening party at General T. Lymans and accepted it. But having made a previous engagement with Mr Brooks to go to Lowell I had agreed with him to pass the preceding and following night at his house. We determined on Monday that to-morrow should be the day for the party to Lowell, and I sent by Charles an excuse, for General Lyman’s Ball.
5. IV:30. Lowell— Cotton Callico Manufactory— Merrimack Locks and Canals— Medford

I had received last evening from George, before I came out from Boston a large mail of despatches and Letters, which having then no time to read, I put into my small trunk, and brought with me to Medford— I found here the 71st number of the English Quarterly Review, published last June which contains an Article upon my Report on Weights and Measures— I read that last Evening, before going to bed, and this morning rose before day-light, and with the help of a flint and steel, given me by Coll. T. H. Perkins, lighted my candle, read the Letters and despatches that I had received last Evening, and wrote nearly an hour before I was called to breakfast— Mr Everett came at 7. and after breakfast he and I went with Mr Brooks in his carriage, through Woburn and Billerica to Lowell— The distance is 19 miles, and we reached the Inn at eleven. This town, was a part of Chelmsford, incorporated in and consists almost entirely of manufacturing establishments for making Cotton Callicoes— Mr Kirke Boott is the Superintendent, and there are three other persons by the name of Moody, Colburn, and Prince employed in various ways in directing the concern— The proprietors are an incorporated company
and Mr Boott says have invested two Millions and a half of dollars in the establishment. There are now several Mills, brick buildings 155 feet long; each with a water wheel of 30 feet diameter. Turning on several floors a number of spinning, carding, dyeing, weaving and printing machines. From the raw Cotton in the bag, to the printed Callico in the Bale, for exportation, we witnessed all the processes; as also the establishment for making the machinery— The spinning Jenny of Sir Richard Arkwright is the first, but there is a succession of machines for each of the other operations, the mechanism of which is quite unknown to me— We saw them all, and among them two, invented by Mr Moody, and unknown in England. There are twelve hundred persons employed in these works, about two thirds of whom are girls from sixteen to twenty-five years of age. They earn upon an average, one dollar 75 cents a week; and work from Sunrise to the dusk of evening, with an interval of half an hour for breakfast, and the same time for dinner— They are boarded in houses built by the company, and rented at an interest of four per cent upon the Capital spent in erecting them— There are already a Stone Episcopalian Church, 70 feet long and 58 feet wide, built for ten thousand dollars, a wooden Meeting House; and another commenced— One Stone Hotel; and another of wood— Mr Boott’s house is a square, and handsome mansion—elegantly furnished— There is another company of Merrimack locks and Canals, from whom the water power and much of the land has been purchased. The cotton factory company, are enlarging their works, and their plan embraces the erection and constant employment of fifty Mills; for all which they have a sufficiency of water power— We took from two to three hours in visiting the various buildings, including that where the machinery is made— This is chiefly of cast iron, and Oak timber— The printing is done by copper rollers, the only article, Mr Boott says, which they can not procure here, and are obliged to smuggle from England— Mr Boott accompanied us over the buildings— About two we returned to the Hotel and dined. Paid a visit to Mrs Boott, a young and elegant English woman and after going to the junction of the Merrimack Canal, with the river, to which place Mr Boott accompanied us we returned to Medford— We met at the Hotel, Mr E. H. Mills, with H. Cabot and Joshua Cabot, who had gone out from Boston, yesterday, and this afternoon returned; with their Ladies— Mr Mills told me that he had taken a cold, which had put him back a little— But Mr Cabot said it was a bleeding of the lungs, which had come upon him yesterday, and deeply alarmed and depressed him— We also saw at the Hotel, Mr Appleton of Boston— Mr Gardner Greene, whose summer residence is at Tewksbury, three or four miles from Lowell had invited me yesterday to visit him, but we did not return that way—our progress was through Bedford, Burlington and Woburn. Lowell is upon Merrimack river; and there is a Bridge near the Hotel, immediately beyond which is Dracut— We arrived at Mr Brooks’s house at Medford between 8 and 9 in the Evening, and Mr Everett immediately proceeded home— I had received an invitation to spend the Evening at Mr B. Pickman’s in Boston, but sent an excuse.
6. IV:30— Boston. Dined at G. Parkman’s— Quincy—

I lighted my candle again this morning, and wrote till seven O’clock— After breakfast, I took leave of Mrs Brooks, her Son Henry, and daughter Abigail (Mr Brooks had already left, for town) and came with Charles over Winter Hill, and Craigie’s Bridge to Boston. On the way, I called and visited Mr Everett— I found Antoine at Hamiltons. He went out to Quincy Tuesday Evening; and walked to town this morning— At Boston I received several visits— Mr Henry Küstner, a merchant of Leipzig, brought me a Letter of Recommendation, from Duke Bernard of Saxe-Weimar dated at Ghent the 5th. of June last— Mr Küstner came with his Son—and informed me that he proposed to visit Washington in October and to embark, on his return to Europe in November— Mr King and Mr Ford, are from Charleston, South-Carolina; and the latter last year delivered at that place an Eulogium upon my father, by an appointment from the City Council. Mr Hammond is the son of William Hammond, Surveyor of the Port of North-Kingston in the District of Newport, Rhode Island— He brought me a Letter from his father, resigning his office, and several Letters earnestly recommending another
Son of the incumbent, Pardon T. Hammond, for the appointment in his place. I told this person, that his father must address a Letter of resignation to the Secretary of the Treasury, and that copies of the Letters recommending his brother, or similar Letters should also be sent to the Secretary. The Letters were very satisfactory, and my own disposition would be favourable to his brother— But the appointment must come through the Treasury Department, and it was necessary that the resignation of his father should be known, that other candidates might have an equal opportunity to offer themselves, and their pretensions— I assured him that I would forward to the Secretary the recommendatory Letters which he now left with me. Dr Waterhouse came from Cambridge, and apologized for not having called upon me before, this Season. He promised to come and dine with me at Quincy next Wednesday— I went with George to the Athenaeum and saw in the adjoining house, Vanderlyn’s Panorama of the Palace and Garden of Versailles. Mr Bates who is now the Secretary of this Institution, shewed me the additions recently made to the Library; and several Books found among those of W. S. Shaw after his decease, and which belong to me— Also the original manuscript of my Lectures upon Rhetoric. Looking into a Catalogue of their Books lately published, I found a list of the Proprietors, but found my own name was not among them. I asked the reason of this, upon which Mr Bates said he had no knowledge of the fact— That there was no regular Record now to be found of the proceedings of the Proprietors at an early period of the Institution, and they had frequently been at a loss to know whether a person was or was not one of the Proprietors. I mentioned to him the collection of antient French Reviews, including Bayle’s Nouvelles de la Republique des Lettres, which were taken by the first Directors, as equivalent to my subscription, to constitute me a life proprietor— He said they had the books, and took me to the chamber where they were but he did not know, from whom they had been received— I told him if no record could be found of the transaction, I should not insist upon my claim; but the fact was so, and I had ceded the books, at the very special instance of Mr Shaw and at the appraisement set upon them by the Directors themselves. On my return from the Athenaeum, I had a visit from Coll. Apthorp, recently from Saratoga and Lebanon, where he had seen my wife— I called at Dr Welsh’s, and then with my Sons George and Charles dined at Dr George Parkman’s— In the Evening I came with George out to Quincy.
7. V:30.— Mr Buzzy’s Roxbury— Dedham factory— Quincy.

At half past ten this morning, I went with George to Mr Buzzy’s at Roxbury; and after a collation at his house, with him in his Carriage to his manufactory of blue Broadcloth at Dedham— There are two separate sets of buildings; one of wood, purchased of an old, broken down cotton factory. The other of brick, chiefly built by Mr Buzzy himself. They are perhaps half a mile distant from each other, and are situated upon Neponset River. We saw here several of the same processes upon wool, which at Lowell we had observed upon Cotton—and several others— The first operation upon the wool is washing, which is performed by water and steam— Then follow the dyeing, spinning and carding weaving, fulling, napping, steam brushing, hot and cold pressing, and packing in Bales of six pieces of twenty yards each—six quarters wide— Their dyeing stuff is Indigo for the Cloth, and Quercitron bark for the yellow listing. They use no other colours. They sell their cloth according to its various qualities from 2 dollars and 3 quarters to 3 dollars and a half a yard, and have a constant demand for more than they can supply— Mr Buzzy was originally the sole proprietors, and gave eighty thousand dollars for the land, buildings and water power. Mr Kuhn is his agent for the management of the business— He gives him a Salary of 1500 dollars a year, and allows him one fifth part of the profits of the establishment, loaning him that portion of the capital employed, with a deduction of the interest on the same amount. The cost of the machinery is forty thousand dollars, and they make about 3000 pieces of Cloth in a year. Their water
power and their buildings, if fully occupied would be competent to the making of one hundred pieces a week. They employ about sixty girls, between 15 and 25 years of age, and as many men. There is besides Mr Kuhn, a Mr Barrows, having much of the direction of the business. The machinery is inferior to that of the cotton manufactory at Lowell—much of it old, and made of wood instead of Cast-iron— The profits upon the business Mr Buzzy admits are very small— The general opinion is that they are at present nothing, and that the proceeds do not indemnify for the expenses— The prices of the Cloths are low, but the competition of foreign broad cloths keeps them down— We returned and dined at Mr Buzzy’s— My brother was to have been of our Company, but did not go— Of the party to the mills, were R. G. Amory, John Gray and his brother Thomas the Minister of Jamaica Plains and Isaac P. DavisLemuel Shaw, and Edward Everett— Mr T. K. Jones came to the dinner— Mrs Buzzy—her widow daughterMrsCharles Davis, and her two daughters, with the husband of the elder, Mr Head, were also at the dinner. Mr Buzzy himself, who engaged in this undertaking upon patriotic motives, still cheers himself with a prospect of success, but has yet realized no encouraging returns. He is wealthy, but supposed by many to have involved his estate by this undertaking— He told me this day that there was another object of public interest, upon which he had it in contemplation, to make a provision by his Will—and upon which he wished to consult me for advice— I said I should very cheerfully give him the best advice in my power upon any subject interesting to him, upon which he should consult me— He asked me to fix a day upon which he might call at Quincy; and converse with me, and we agreed upon next Thursday afternoon. I returned with George to Quincy, this evening, and found at my brothers Mr Joseph Harrod of Portland, with George Foster, a young Son of Mr Phineas Foster of Boston.

Miss Sparhawk went away this morning—as did Mr Harrod with George Foster. My brother’s daughter Elizabeth also went to Boston, to visit Miss Selden, and returned in the Evening— I had visits from Mr Whitney, and from Mr William Emmons, who sometimes styles himself a professor of Oratory and Belles Lettres, and is sometimes called by others Orator Emmons.— He brought a subscription paper for the publication of a Poem in four Volumes upon the late War, by his brother Richard Emmons, a clergyman residing in the State of Ohio. I declined subscribing, but paid him for a copy of the work, to be sent me, when it is published— He also gave me six of his own Orations, Addresses Poems and Caucus speeches, and sold me a copy of his republication of the trial of the British Soldiers at Boston in 1770— Mr Winslow is from Charleston, South-Carolina, and Mrs Pickering is his Sister. With my brother and my Son George I dined at Mr Quincy’s— The company was of several Gentlemen from Boston, and Mr Küstner— There were I. P. Davis, C Loring, Savage. C. P. Curtis, Mr Miller Harding, and some others— Davis said a number of Gentlemen at Boston, proposed a fishing party below the Light-house, to go out in the Steam boat; and asked me to fix the day— I mentioned Tuesday the 18th. to which he agreed— Mr Harding who is a painter, asked me to sit to him, for my Portrait—to which I consented. He said he should want four sittings, each of an hour; and I promised to call at his room next Friday at Noon, for the first— We paid a visit to Mr Quincy’s Salt-works, and after dark I walked home with George— I found Charles had come out from Boston— I planted this day 12. Rare-ripe peach-stones in a row in my Summer house Cellar.
9. V:30.— Roxbury— Genl. Dearborn’s— Quincy.

Heard Mr Whitney, this Morning from Job 19.25. [“]For I know that my Redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the Earth: 26. And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God: 27. Whom I shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold and not another: though my reins be consumed within me.” This was a funeral discourse, preached on the occasion of the decease of Mrs Arnold, a Sister of Ebenezer and Josiah Adams, and who died the week before last— In commenting upon the text however, Mr Whitney observed that although this
passage had been understood by some as having reference to the immortality of the soul, that construction of it was probably not correct— That the author of the Book of Job was unknown, some supposing it to be Moses—others Ezekiel, but if one of the Hebrew Books, it was among the most antient of the Scriptures— That under the old testament dispensation, the Hebrews had no knowledge of a future State— Life and immortality having been brought to light by the Gospel of Jesus Christ — He gave then an exposition of the text, as he understood it, considering it as a part of Jobs discourse, and applicable exclusively to his own condition, without reference either to a future State, or to Christ as the Redeemer— In the 23d. verse of this same chapter, Job expresses the wish that his words were printed in a Book from which there would be as much reason to infer that the art of printing was practised in those days, as that Christ the Redeemer, or the immortality of the Soul, are revealed in Mr Whitney’s text— The words though, worms andbody, in the 26th. verse, are supplied by the English translators, and give a meaning altogether conjectural to the original passage—the true explanation of which is very difficult— Mr Whitney’s afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 6.5. “And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are: for they love to pray standing in the synagogues, and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men— Verily I say unto you they have their reward. 6. But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet; and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret, and thy Father which seeth in secret, shall reward thee openly.” The doctrine from this text is obvious, and it is one of the admirable precepts of Christian morality— Immediately after the Afternoon service I went with Charles into the Cellar of the Temple, now building to examine the place for the tomb of my father and mother—upon which however I did not finally fix. I then rode with George to General H. A. S. Dearborn’s at Roxbury— I visited his Garden, which is very tastefully laid out, on the side of a barren and rocky hill. He has beds sown from the seed or acorn, of rock maple, elm, white Oaks and English Oaks; the Illinois or Pecane Nut, the Button wood, and the Honey Locust. He has also many other trees, indigenous and exotic, most of them very flourishing— He uses to cover the wounds of trees a composition made of a quart of tar, and a pound of beeswax melted together and then mixed with a pound of red Ochre. He gave us some fruit, fair but not highly flavoured— One nectarine of which I preserved the stone— On returning home I found Mr Marston here; and my Son Charles very sick with a sudden attack of Cholera Morbus.

Charles with the aid of an emetic which operated favourably was much recovered this morning, and went this afternoon with my Chaise into Boston, and returned in the Evening. Mr Frink Roberts came this morning, with an other person also named Roberts, to renew his solicitation for an appointment in the Custom House at Boston. I referred him again to the Collector, Genl. Dearborn, who I said knew his qualifications for such an Office better than I could. He asked me for a Letter to General Dearborn, recommending him, which I declined giving— Mr Charles Pinkney, the Secretary of the Legation at St Petersburg soon afterwards came in. He arrived yesterday at Boston, after a passage of 53 days from Cronstadt— Says he has had a dreadful typhus fever, and was compelled to come home, to save his life— His physician having assured him that if he remained in Russia he would certainly die. He said he had come to report himself to me; and believed he should this evening proceed on his way to Washington— He has every appearance of a ruin, bodily and mental— Mr John A. Bates came to apply for an appointment of purser in the Navy— He brought a Letter of recommendation from Amos Binney, with several others. He received from Commodore Hull, an acting appointment, in the Pacific, and served under it as Purser, three years—but on Hull’s return to this Country, it was revoked by the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Bates’s application to the Navy Department was made in 1823. and is there on file; with the recommendations of which he brought me copies. I promised to mention his name to the Secretary of the Navy. I walked with George at Noon to the Temple; and examined the cellar, with a view to selecting the spot for the tomb— I saw and conversed with Mr William Wood, but came yet to no final determination— Continued the walk to the foot of Penn’s
Hill, and called as I had promised, to see Harvey Field, but he was gone to Brighton— I saw his father Joseph Field, his mother, and his wife, who promised to ask him to call upon me to-morrow Morning. In the evening I attended a party at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— The company was of about thirty persons of both sexes— Charles brought me out from Boston, a voluminous mail of despatches and Letters, the reading of which occupied me till near Midnight— Among them, Letters from J. R. Poinsett, the Minister to Mexico, and from B. T. Watts, Chargé d’Affaires in Colombia—in vindication each of his own conduct. He also brought intelligence of the decease of George Canning, the British Secretary of State for foreign Affairs—an implacable and rancorous enemy of the United States— May this event, in the order of Providence, avert all the evils, which he would if permitted have drawn down upon us; and all-evil Councils formed against our peace and prosperity be baffled and defeated— I went out this afternoon with Farrar, and staked off the ground to be set off for a Nursery of trees— He is to plough it up immediately— After which it is to be fenced off. I also planted a Row of 12 Horse plums in the Summer House cellar.
11. V:15— Hingham— Dined at E. Gay’s—Quincy.

My Sons George and Charles went to Boston in the Stage—and Mrs Adams, with her Son Isaac Hull, in my brother’s Chaise— Harvey Field called upon me, to speak about his project of building a house, and my land in his neighbourhood— He wishes to have the road straitened, and to build me a wall fence— Says there is land wanted about there for house lots, for which my land is well suited— A spot is particularly needed for a woman’s school, for children, in that part of the town. He also offered me his Stock in the Quincy Canal, and I agreed to take it at the price fixed by himself— He gave me some details concerning it, from which I infer his expectation that it will yield about four per Cent interest upon the capital employed— He promised to bring me the certificate of Shares transferred to me, and a note, to-morrow— Peter Turner came to enquire about the lot of land belonging to my father, which could not be found last Summer, but was surveyed after I went to Washington, and part of which it appears Mr Turner had sold by mistake as belonging to my uncle. I promised to let him know when I could take a morning to go out with him, and fix the bounds between him and me, that all future dispute might be avoided— I went with my brother to Hingham, and dined with Mr Ebenezer Gay— Mr Brooks the Minister, Thomas and Edward Thaxter, T. Loring, Dr Fiske and his wife, a Mr Moorfield, and two or three others, with Mrs Gay and six children constituted the company. Mrs Gay, gave me a letter from the wife of J. B. Amedey, soliciting for him a pardon— I returned in the Evening with my brother to Quincy— Mrs Adams also returned from Boston— Evening fair and warm— I planted a Nectarine Stone in my seedling bucket. N. 4— Made a draught of an Agreement with the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund, for the construction of the Tomb of my father and mother.

I sent for Henry Wood, who called on me this Morning— I went with him and examined again the cellar under the Temple, to determine upon the spot where the Tomb shall be constructed— I took with me the two plans of a Tomb which he had furnished me last Summer; but found there must be a variation from them to adapt the construction to the cellar as it has been made— I marked two places without deciding positively between them, and requested Mr Wood, to furnish me an estimate of the cost for which he would undertake the work, which he promised to do. I also visited with him the burying yard, and the monuments there erected by my father over the graves of his ancestors. There are two of those monuments— That of the founder of the family, who died in 1646. and that of his grandson, my father’s grandfather Joseph Adams junr. which consist only of two Stones one a cube 6 feet long—three feet wide, and two feet high, with a flat stone 7 feet long 4 feet wide and 9 inches thick to cover it— The two others—that of his own father and Mother, and that of his great Grandfather, Joseph Adams senior, are made of several stones comparatively smaller connected together with mortar, covered in like manner, with a large flat Stone. But it is apparent that the solid cubes only will be of much durability— The small cemented stones are already coming apart— I am satisfied also that the marble Slabs on which the Epitaphs are engraved, and soldered into the granit with lead, will all be of short continuance— All the most antient grave-stones in the yard of granite; and all had the marble slab
bearing the obituary inscription, bedded in the Stone, and doubtless soldered in with lead; but every one of the marbles without exception is lost, and the granite stones remain, almost unaltered; and all the inscriptions engraven on them are yet legible— Dr. and Mrs Waterhouse came from Cambridge and dined with us— I had an afternoon visit from Judge E. H. Robins. Harvey Field came, and I took his six Shares in the Quincy Canal Corporation; and a note from the Treasurer: for which I gave him a check on the U.S. Branch Bank, Boston; with a Letter to the Cashier S Frothingham, enclosing a check on the Branch Bank Boston.— A Mr Noah Nichols of Cohasset; a Revolutionary Pensioner, came to state a claim for certain rations, during his term of service in addition to those which he had received— I advised him to address his claim and send his vouchers to the Secretary of War. I called in the Evening at Mr T. Greenleaf’s, and gave him to read the draught of Agreement by Indenture which I had prepared; and which he offered to submit to the Supervisors at a Meeting which he would call— I met there Mr and Mrs Lemuel Bracket. On returning home I found George, who had come out this Evening from Boston— I read an hour this morning by Lamplight.

I began an examination of the Papers of reference to the Execution of my fathers Will, and on comparing the Deeds, executed by the Executors to me on the fourth of October last, with the plans then taken by Mather Withington. I found one of the plans, that of the Quincy Woodlot missing. There is however a plan of the same lot, one of the five on the Survey of Jedidiah Bass taken in 1785— There appear to be four lots which were not sold last year, and which are yet to be appraised, and a return of the appraisement to be made at the probate Court— But the bounds are not yet fully ascertained, nor can they be without further surveys— Great part of this morning was absorbed in examining these Papers with George, and I found much to be done for which I shall not now have time— I set apart the plans of the Lots yet to be sold— Visit from Mr Thorndike, with whom I engaged to dine at Beverley on Wednesday the 26th. of this Month—from Mr James Brooks, who applied for Appointment of Purser in the Navy, and brought Letters of Recommendation from Commodore Chauncey whose Secretary he has been; from Mr Webster and E. Everett. Mr Price Greenleaf called after dinner and Mr Buzzy, who communicated his intention to appropriate by Will a portion of his Estate, to the establishment of a Literary Institution, for the improvement of Agriculture and Horticulture, and as connected with them of Manufactures and Chemistry. He told me that having no Son; and only one daughter, a widow with three daughters, the idea had become very unpleasant to him that the Estate which he had so painfully acquired would after his decease, like some others which he named be scattered to the four winds of Heaven. That about a year since, being alarmed at the state of his own health he made and executed his Will: in which he had expressed his own intentions— But that being now restored to health he had given it to Lemuel Shaw, a lawyer to draw it up again in technical form, so that his purposes may not be defeated by the want of any legal formality— His object was to secure to his wife during her life the income of all his Estate, real and personal, she paying to his daughter an annuity of 3000 dollars a year—after the decease of his wife he reserved to his daughter an annuity of 5000 dollars a year during her life and after her decease 2000 dollars a year to each of her daughters— He proposed to vest the whole Estate in seven Executors and Trustees who after carrying into effect those provisions for his family, and sundry small bequests should together with the judges of the Supreme Court for the time being should apply the remainder
of it to the public purposes above mentioned— He asked my opinion of the whole design—and whether I was willing to be named as one of the Executors and Trustees of the Will— I said that with regard to the provision to be made for his family, particularly his daughter and Grand daughters, I thought he should himself be the exclusive judge— Advice upon that subject from others, might be liable to objection, as an interference with prospects and expectations, which should be exempt from all external influence— That the sufficiency of a provision for a person in the situation of his daughter was a matter of relative consideration—to be compared not with the mere wants of necessity, but with the Style in which she had been accustomed to live as his daughter, and with the expectations which she might reasonably form from the extent of his wealth— But assuming that point as settled in his mind, and that he had resolved to apply to public uses a portion of his Estate, I knew of no object more laudable, or which would redound more to his own reputation, and lead to useful results than that which he proposed. That I thought he would do well to consider the expediency of separating the mere Execution of his Will, from the Trust to which he meant to devote a part of his Estate— That he might if he pleased name the same persons upon both; but the Executors must be under Bonds— Their duties would be temporary, and their transactions sanctioned by the probate Courts of the several Counties in which his real Estates are situated— But the Trust would be a permanent thing: destined to survive all the individual Trustees, and which might perhaps require an Act of incorporation, to give it legal succession and perpetuity. As to the proposal that he should name me as one of his Executors and Trustees I wished to take a few days to consider of it, and would then answer him. The only objection that now occurred to me, was my public situation which while it continued would make it impossible for me to act as his Executor— This however would cease after a short time, and when once released from the Public Service, should my life and health be preserved I shall be master of my own time, and could have no greater happiness than to devote it to such purposes of public beneficence as he proposed. He said he had intended to have brought his Will with him for my perusal; but it was in the hands of Mr Shaw, and was not yet quite finished. That before my return to Washington he would come over again and bring it with him— He said Mr Ruel Williams whom he considered as one of the first Lawyers in the State of Maine: and who was the Agent of his Lands there would be one of his Executors and Trustees. He considered his lands in Maine as worth at least 150000 dollars; and they had cost him 300000— He had eight Stores in Boston— A dwelling House and Land in Summer Street, for which he had been two years since offered 100000 dollars. His house and lands in Roxbury—and his manufacturing establishment at Dedham, which had hitherto yielded him no profit— Mr Buzzy’s daughter Mrs Davis was with him, and went to visit Mrs Cutler, but did not come in— Mr Joseph Russell called, and I engaged to dine with him in Boston, next Saturday week. I rode with George to the Railway; intending to visit Col.l Perkins, but he was not there. We went up to the Stone pyramid that he is building on the highest summit of the Railway ledge— But in returning we missed our way, and got into a cart way which led us nearly three miles through the woods; and brought us out at the corner West of Mr Rowe’s house in Milton. We had then upwards of a mile walk to get back to the Railway Stone house where I had left my Horse and Chaise. When we reached there it was completely dark, but we got home without accident about 8. in the Evening. I gathered about a Quart of Black Oak and Gray-Oak Acorns to plant.
14. V. Boston.

George came to Boston in the Stage, and I came in the Chaise with Antoine. I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and saw his wife and two daughters; and Louisa Smith, to whom I delivered a Letter from Mrs Clark at Utica— I then came to the Exchange Hotel where Mr Davis and Mr Quincy, immediately afterwards called upon me— I agreed with Mr Davis if the weather should be fair next Tuesday, to come into Boston, and go with a party of Gentlemen, upon a fishing excursion in the Steam boat. Mr Quincy went with me to Mr Harding the Painter’s—to whom I sat, about an hour for my Portrait. I dined with my Son Charles at Mr Joseph Coolidge’s— Mrs T. M. Randolph the daughter of Mr
Jefferson, and her daughter, wife of Mr Joseph Coolidge junr. were there; also two Sons and two daughters of Mr Coolidge— Mr Kerr the member of Congress from Maryland, Mr P. C. Brooks, Lloyd N. Rogers, E. Everett, Dr. George Parkman, Loammi Baldwin, Professor Farrar, and two or three others— I called in the Evening at Mr B. L. Pickman’s, and at Judge Hall’s. He walked with me to my lodgings where he sat in conversation with me about half an hour— The conversation was painful to me, as he touched successively upon almost every topic of public concern, which wears inauspicious aspects— He spoke in the Spirit of friendship, and perhaps expecting from me assurances that would remove some of his apprehensions. I had none to give.
15. IV. Charlestown Navy Yard— Winter Hill— Boston— Quincy.

I had little sleep, and hearing the morning Clocks strike four, arose, lighted my candles and wrote a Letter to R. Rush— This is one of the mercies indulged me, and forms much of the consolation of my life— It occupied me and shortened the time till breakfast. Soon after ten, I went and gave a second sitting to Mr Harding. While I was there Harriet Welsh came, and invited me to go and see the Paintings of Miss Scollay which I did. She paints Landscapes, and has particularly two, of Scenes from two of Scott’s Novels, which are very beautifully done— I saw Mrs Scollay also—the first time for nearly twenty years— I then went with my Sons George and Charles to the Navy-Yard at Charlestown, where I was received by Commodore Morris and the other Officers at the Yard— Viewed the works barely commenced of the Dock, superintended by Loammi Baldwin and the line of Battle ship Virginia, and Sloop of War Falmouth, now on the Stocks— Mr Baldwin also shewed me the plan of the dock, as it is contemplated— We proceeded thence and dined with Mr Everett at Winter Hill— It was mostly a family party— Mr P. C. Brooks and his three daughters, P. C. Brooks junr. and his wife; Mr Frothingham, Gorham Brooks were there with Mr and Mrs Blodget, and a Mr Thomson, an Englishman— While we were at table there came up a violent gust of wind, followed by a single heavy clap of thunder, and a light shower in the midst of which I came away with George, leaving Charles, who proposed to go with Mr Brooks to Medford— I returned with George in the Carriage to Boston—and then came in the Chaise out to Quincy; much in the dark. Here I found an invitation from Mr George W. Beale to an evening party which I attended.— The usual Society of Quincy were there, with some additions from Milton among them a Mr Morton, a Brother of my old Classmate of that name, who has been many years deceased— When we came home I found a voluminous mail of Letters and despatches; the reading of which employed me till Midnight, and was then not completed. Mr Gallatin signed on the 6th. of August two Conventions with Great Britain, which I hope will promote Peace with that Nation, and which relieve me from much anxiety. J. J. Appleton has also signed a Treaty with Sweden.
16. VI. Bath—

I took a bath at seven this morning, at the wharf with my nephews John and Joseph, and Antoine. Probably the last for the Season. The morning was fine, but the water very cold. Heard Mr Brooks of Hingham this morning from Hebrews 2.9. “But we see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels for the suffering of death, crowned with glory and honour; that he by the grace of God should taste death for every man. 10. For it became him for whom are all things, and by whom are all things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to make the Captain of their salvation perfect through sufferings.” An argumentative unitarian discourse, urging the mere human nature of Christ, from the direct assertion in the text that Jesus was made, lower than the Angels, and from the motive assigned that he might be made perfect by suffering death for the salvation of man. The argument most forcibly put was, that the death of Christ having been effected as an example to the rest of mankind, it could bear that character, and answer that purpose, only in as much as his nature was the same as theirs— For that if his power was of a different nature from
that of other men, his endurance of suffering could not operate as an example to them. The afternoon Sermon was from Luke 24–46. “And said unto them, Thus it is written, and thus it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day: 47. And that repentance, and remission of sins should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem. 48. And ye are witnesses of these things.”— The drift of this Sermon was to shew from the text and from the peculiar character of the Christian religion that it was adapted to all mankind and worthy of universal acceptance— Mr Brooks dined with us— My Son John arrived here this afternoon from New-York which he left last Friday— My wife had departed thence to return to Washington last Wednesday— Mr Marston with his relatives Messrs.Watson and Taylor were here in the Evening. I received among the Letters which I found here last Night one from N. Frye junr. Guardian of T. J. Hellen, with an order from R. Smith Cashier U.S. Branch Bank Washington, upon the Cashier of the Branch Bank, Boston—for 300 dollars on account.
17. V:30. Weymouth— Quincy.

George went this morning to Boston— Mr Edward Miller called with his Son. He had a subscription paper from Dr Thacher of Plymouth for the publication of a biography of eminent American Physicians, of which I promised to take a copy upon the subscription of my Son John. Charles with Miss Brooks went and dined at Mr Tufts in Weymouth— They stopped here on their way—and proceeding soon after their horse fell and threw them both out of the Chaise— They were not seriously hurt, returned here and sent for another horse and Chaise with which they went on to Weymouth— I called at the shop of Mr Brigham, the Treasurer of the Quincy Canal Corporation and obtained from him a new certificate for the share, which I had transferred to my Son George— I took the occasion to look over the Record of their proceedings hitherto; and found some information upon the state of their affairs. Their proceedings have been irregular and several of the first proprietors abandoned them before the work was completed. Edward Miller told me he had given away his share to get rid of all concern in the undertaking.— He thinks the profits will not exceed three per Cent a year upon the Stock— The information I received from Mr Brigham does not promise more— After dinner I went with my Son John, and visited Mr Tufts and his family at Weymouth— My brotherswife and daughter Elizabeth, and son Joseph were also there— Mrs Tarbell, and Mercy and Tufts were at home— Charles and Miss Brooks had dined there, and soon afterwards left us to return to Boston— We came home in the dusk of Evening— In my Summer house cellar George yesterday discovered one Shagbark walnut newly up, and I this day found another.
18. IV:30. Boston— Steam Boat Fishing party— George’s Island— Tilestone’s wharf.

I came to Boston this morning with my Son John, and immediately embarked at Tilestone’s wharf in the Nahant Steam-boat Ousatonic upon a fishing party below the Light House. We left the wharf at half past nine— There were on board upwards of thirty persons, chiefly of my old acquaintance— There were Loammi Baldwin, George Blake, Peter C. Brooks. David L. Child, Joseph Coolidge—Isaac P. Davis. H. A. S. Dearborn, Edward Everett Gallagher. Benjn Gorham. John Gray, F. C. Gray, Gardner GreeneJohn Hubbard, Benjamin Joy, Caleb Loring, Charles Morris, Thomas H. Perkins. Josiah Quincy, Robins, Nathanl. Silsbee, Joseph Story, Bryant P. Tilden Trevett, my Sons George and John, and several others some of whom I did not know. On going down I made some additional observations upon the topography of the harbour: Having taken my pocket compass with me, I found it agreed well with the box Compass that was on board the Boat. They had also a small Chart from a Survey made a few years since by Captain Wadsworth of the Navy. The light-House is three leagues distant from the City. The Islands in the harbour are numerous, and many of them so interlocked in the perspective that it requires a practised eye to distinguish many of them from one another. We passed the Light about eleven, and anchored for a fishing ground an hour afterwards. Having little success
there, the anchor was weighed and we proceeded to a spot where there were several fishing smacks laying to, with small boats and from them, with one man in each, fishing for the market— They call them dories. It was about eight miles distant from the light-house which bore from it N.N.E. and on the Eastern Shore of the bay ranging towards Cape Ann there is a white barn about the same distance bearing E.S.E.— Here we fished about 2 hours and caught from 60 to 70 fish. Cod— Haddock— Dog fish— flounders, Mackarel, and Sculpins. I caught a single Haddock, and three or four Mackarel— We had again but a short time for fishing and soon after 3 O’Clock weighed anchor to return— After coming within the Light, we anchored off George’s Island, and dined— After dinner I landed upon the Island, with Commodore Morris, Captain Gallagher, General Dearborn, Mr Quincy and Mr Baldwin, and viewed the Sea wall building, by the United States for the preservation of the Harbour— The wall is to consist of ten courses of Granite Stone, rising in steps; five of which are below the surface of the ground, and are already laid— The Superintendent of the work, Captain Smith was absent, in Boston— It was near 8 in the Evening when we got back to Tilestone’s wharf, and I came to the Exchange Hotel— Found there W. W. Seaton just arrived from Washington. Mr Quincy afterwards came, and introduced to me a Mr Banks, an Englishman, much occupied with researches of Heraldry; and enquiring particularly into the genealogy of the name of Quincy in this Country.
19. V:45.— Equinoctial Storm. Cambridge— Dined at T. Fuller’s.— Boston.

There came on in the Night, a Northeasterly storm with rain, which with exception of an interval towards noon continued through the day, and increased in violence this Evening— I had engaged to visit this morning the Botanic Garden at Cambridge: to dine with Mr Fuller to go and spend the Night at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s in Medford, and to go upon an excursion up the Middlesex Canal to-morrow— But this was no day for lounging in a Garden— Mr Fuller called on me this Morning at ten, and I agreed with him to postpone my visit to the garden, of which he gave notice to Mr Nuttall who has the care of it. Mr Coolidge also came and from the aspect of the weather anticipating the probable continuance of the storm, tomorrow, proposed to postpone the excursion up the canal; to which I assented: and I desired my Son Charles to send a notice to Mr Brooks, not to expect me at Medford this Evening— I sat the third time to Mr Harding, and met at his room Franklin Dexter, with whom I had a pleasant conversation, and promised him to visit his Mother— I had visits from Mr Allen, member of Congress from this State, and from Mr Pearce of Rhode-Island, with the Collector of Bristol, and Dr. Case— Also from Mr Jonathan Mason, and Mr Benjamin Joy, who brought with him and shewed me two pieces of Sail-Cloth from the manufactory of which he is proprietor, in the State of New-York— He has a contract with the Commissioners of the Navy for the supply of all that he can furnish— He made in the course of the last year more than three thousand Bolts— Mr James H. Foster was here this morning, and told me that the directors of the Boylston Market had determined to make one hundred new Shares of their Stock and to sell them to morrow at Auction— I authorised him to purchase for me to the extent of 25 Shares if they should be sold within a certain limit— Thomas J. Hellen, and Charles, dined with John at the Exchange Hotel, and I with Mr Fuller at Cambridge— The company was of 20 persons, among whom Mrs T. M. Randolph, Mr and Mrs Joseph Coolidge junr.Dr. Waterhouse, Genl H. A. S. Dearborn, Major Melville, Dr Hill, Mr E. Everett, Professors
Hedge and Farrar, a Mr Follen a German, now in some Office at the University, J. T. Austin, Isaac Munro of Baltimore, and two or three others— Returning to Boston in the Evening, I stopped at Dr Welsh’s, and saw him, his Son Thomas and daughter Harriet; and my Son George who was not well— The evening was too stormy for paying visits— I came early to the Exchange, and wrote till near eleven at Night.
20. V:45. Quincy— Storm continues.

I called this morning upon Mr James H. Foster, and advised with him further, respecting the purchase of some of the new constituted shares in the Boylston Market; the sale of which was to be at auction this day— After breakfast I rode with my Son John out to Quincy—the North-East Equinoctial continuing, the whole day. My brother with his Son John Quincy, returned this afternoon from the Court at Dedham— Mr Ebenezer Adams called here and spoke of the land at the old Mill Pond, and a straightening of the brook there; for which he wished me to inspect the land— I must do it some day the week after next, if at all this year— I was occupied nearly the whole remnant of the day after I arrived here, In reading the proceedings of the Court Martial upon the trial of Lieutt Coll Richard Smith of the Marine Corps— I approved the Sentence of the Court, and wrote a short Letter to the Secretary of the Navy.
21. V. Lamp-light.— Rain and Fog.

The heavy gale subsided in the course of the Night, but the rain continued with short intervals the whole of this day and Evening, with a damp, sultry atmosphere, and thick fog. I read over again the Correspondence of George Davis with Mr Graham the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, Graham, and wrote a short Letter, enclosing it to Mr Rush— About Noon I called upon Mr Daniel Greenleaf, and told him I had some thoughts of building a house upon Mount Wollaston and enquired if he could accommodate me so far as to open through his land an avenue from the mound to the Neponset Bridge road— He expressed a willingness to comply, and went out with me on the road between his House and the Meeting House to view the ground in that direction. The road there however, would afford little accommodation to me; and the other he said would be both inconvenient and expensive to him, as it would split in two his most valuable meadow land, and require him to make and maintain a mile and a half of fencing. He agreed with me to go over the ground again some day when the sky should be clear. He spoke also of this Quincy Canal, and its Proprietors, somewhat disadvantageously, and offered me his own share in it; but asked the same for it that I had given for the shares of Harvey Field— Though he said the value of the shares before I had bought these was only seventy-five dollars. It had been as low as fifteen; and Edward Miller had actually given away his share. This afternoon Mr Thomas Greenleaf came with Mr Parris, the Architect of the Temple, and shewed me the plans of its projected interior arrangement, and of the steeple— This Gothic superaddition has an incongruous appearance upon a building of Grecian Architecture; and we discussed the question whether it would be least exceptionable with one, two or three Stories—The plan has it of two. For the appearance of the building one—the Square turret of Stone would be best— But the lofty Spire to be descried at a distance and mingling with moral and religious associations would require three. Something was said of the pitch of the roof, which upon the plan is at an angle of 22 1/2 degrees, or one fourth of a right angle— Mr Finn the manager of the federal Street Theatre came out from Boston, with a Letter from George to John and invited me to attend at their performance next Tuesday, the day of the Review. I had already engaged to attend at the new Tremont Street Theatre, which is to be opened on Monday, under the management of Mr Pelby— I promised Mr Finn however to attend in Federal Street, some day of the week after next, and to give him notice of the day, next week. The new and old Theatres are now rivals, but Boston cannot permanently support two— I employed the Evening in answering a Letter of George Sullivan.
22. V:30. Boston— Dined at Joseph Russell’s— Quincy.

I received this morning a Letter from James H. Foster informing me that he had made no purchase for me of the Boylston Market Shares they having all sold beyond my limits. Mr Lemuel Bracket called, and proposed to me to purchase of him a lot of woodland of fifteen Acres at Pine Hill, adjoining a lot of mine— He asked 30 dollars an Acre for it and said it had been appraised upon the settlement of his father’s Estate last year as 27. I asked for his Deeds which he said he would bring me, and I said the land must be surveyed, and if upon viewing it I should be satisfied with it, I might probably take it. I went to Boston with John, called and paid a visit to Mrs Dexter, sat the fourth time to Mr Harding, received at the Exchange Hotel a packet of despatches from the Department of State and a Letter from Mr Rush— Thomas. J. Hellen was there, and has concluded to leave Cambridge and go to Washington— I called at Dr Welsh’s, and found him and his Son John and my Son George at dinner— George is so much engaged in preparing for the brigade Review, that he could not go out to Quincy. I dined with Mr Joseph Russell— Mrs Russell, Miss Gore her daughter, and Miss Gardner— R. G. Amory, I. P. Davis, E. Everett, J. Hubbard, B. Joy, Mr Lee, Commodore MorrisT. H. Perkins, R. Shepherd, and Charles Codman were there. Joseph Hall came in after dinner— We sat late, but I returned to the Exchange and came back with John to Quincy, in a very dark Evening. The bell for nine O’Clock rang just after we got home. I met in the Street, at Boston Mr Caleb Loring and promised to dine with him next Saturday. The despatches sent me from the Department of State were from A. Gallatin to 14. Augt. one number being yet to come.
23. V:15. Lamplight

Heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from Matthew 13.24. “Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, the kingdom of Heaven is likened unto a Man which sowed good seed in his field. 25 But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way. 26. But when the blade was sprung up, and brought forth fruit, then appeared the tares also. 27. So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow good seed in thy field? from whence then hath it tares? 28. He said unto them, An enemy hath done this. The servants said unto him, wilt thou then that we go and gather them up? 29. But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them. 30. Let both grow together until the harvest: and in the time of harvest I will say to the reapers, gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them: but gather the wheat into my barn.” Mr Whitney commented upon this parable, and also upon the explanation of it given by Jesus himself to his disciples as afterwards recorded in the same chapter. He declared however that he did not understand it as importing the eternity of future punishment— He argued against this not from his text but because he thought it inconsistent with the goodness of God— The text certainly gives me countenance to the idea that the punishment of the wicked hereafter will ever end. The term of punishment is as unlimited as the term of reward— Mr Whitney’s afternoon Sermon was from 1 Thessalonians. 5.17. “Pray without ceasing.” And this precept he said was to be received with some qualification— It meant that prayer should be frequent and fervent; and in behalf of others as well as of the suppliant himself. He also indicated the purport of the prayer adapted to the characters and circumstances of those for whom it is made—and especially of vicious and criminal persons. A Christian preacher discoursing upon prayer, might find his ideas much enlarged and improved by reading the dialogue of Plato upon that subject— Mr Quincy came home with me, from the afternoon meeting, and we had conversation upon the further execution of my father’s will— I shewed him the draft of an Account N. 4 to be settled at the Probate Office next week, which he examined and approved. I also shewed him the Plans of the Woodlots not sold
last year, and proposed that in order to trace effectively their boundaries, so that the Executors may safely sell them and give good titles, a new survey should be made of the whole tract of the 600 Acres— But he thought this would prove too troublesome, and that the boundaries might be found by a shorter process—that is by calling for the deeds of those who have encroached upon our bounds— This subject was therefore left for further consideration— In the Evening there was a meeting of the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund; all the members present— My draft of an Agreement for the construction of a Tomb, with an obituary tablet was read and discussed; and with an amendment proposed by Mr Quincy, approved. The formal meeting of the Supervisors for the acceptance of it, is to be tomorrow morning— My Son John was quite unwell this day; and I was so in the Evening, and retired early to bed.
24. VI. Visit to the Railway— Coll. T. H. Perkins.

I had an indifferent night; afflicted with the sore throat and some fever: I found myself better this morning but threatened with a return of the Catarrhal cough—which tormented me last Summer— Henry Wood called this morning and brought a model of the monuments for my Father and Mother, and an Estimate of the Expense of constructing the Tomb: with the Monuments amounting to more than 400 dollars— I engaged him to undertake and finish the work, and took his papers to draw up a written agreement to that effect. Deacon Spear came, and spoke of the land offered for Sale by Lemuel Bracket; and also offered me sixty Acres of Wood land in the 600 Acres at 30 dollars an Acre— I told him I could not come to a determination until I should have viewed the Land; nor without a survey by which its boundaries should be ascertained. He thought Mr Bracket would object to the expense of the survey, unless I would agree to take the land, before it should be made— I said I could make no positive promise; and from the difficulties we were experiencing in ascertaining my father’s Lands I had been warned never to purchase any woodland without a Survey and a Plan. He said he should at all Events have a survey of the lands that he offered, but it cannot be made before I go away. He spoke also of the Temple, said they were wanting to borrow more money; and did not know where they should get it unless I would lend them further— I said there was a balance of about fourteen hundred dollars in the hands of the Executors of my father, which could not now be distributed, and which we might lend— He spoke with some anxiety about the expense they were incurring in the building of the Temple—said many persons were dissatisfied with it; and he expected several would go off. I am not without much concern upon this subject myself— I rode to the Railway and met Coll T. H. Perkins at the Stone house. He shewed me the plans of a Hotel for which he has already contracted, to be built at the Road, and I rode with him down to the wharf on Neponset River— I met three of the Cars carried by one horse going to the wharf, and saw the new Car; with an improvement invented by Mr Bryant for suspending the plank upon which the Stones rest, under the Car— I rode home with Coll. Perkins— In the afternoon Mr John Whitney came, and paid me for the rent of my pew in the Meeting House N. 1 for the last year, and the agreement for his occupation of it was continued for another year— In the Evening I wrote some notes for the Executors of my father’s Will; related to the Lots of Woodland, not yet appraised or sold.
25. IV.45. Lamplight— Boston— Third Brigade Review— Tremont Theatre.

Elisha Turner came this morning, and promised to send me a coat next Monday. I sent word to Peter Turner that I would go with him next Monday into the woods—to settle the boundaries of our adjoining dominions—to which he agreed— Yesterday afternoon I planted in the Summer Garden cellar 18 Pear Cones, with the seeds in them 9. St. Michaels and 9. of Sugar Pears in a row on the North side, from West to East—and 21. whole peaches, in a row from South to North, between the two rows of Shagbarks, of this years growth. I came in to Boston this morning with John. Stopped at Mather Withington’s in Dorchester; left with him the plans, Deeds, and Will, relating to the unsold Woodlots, and explained to him my reasons for believing that his plan of the 4 acre owen, and the adjoining six Acre lots, is of lands also included in his plan of the Beale lot— He seemed unwilling to believe this, but promised to come next Monday, if the weather is fair, and go into the woods again.
On alighting in Boston, I found at the Hotel, the Committee of five Members from the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanick Association, whom I had agreed to meet here at Noon, and who invited me to attend the Triennial celebration of the Society, and to dine with them at Faneuil Hall, on Thursday the 4th. of next Month—which invitation I accepted— Mr Quincy, the Mayor immediately afterwards called, and accompanied me to the Council Chamber, where we found Governor Lincoln, Lieutt Governor Winthrop and some other Gentlemen— The Governor in full Uniform, with his two Aids— He proceeded to the Common escorted by the Cadet Company: but I went privately and attended only by an Officer of the Staff— I had accepted the invitation of General Lyman, on condition that I should be considered as a private Citizen; present only as a visitor— We met in the Tent of the Brigadier General. The Governor passed in review the third Brigade, drawn up in line— We then returned to the tent and dined with the Brigadier General and a number of the Officers— After dinner various evolutions were performed, by the Corps upon the field, till near Sunset when they were discharged— The Governor returned, escorted by the Cadets to the Council Chamber, and I attended him. We then went to tea at Coll. James T. Austin’s, where with other company I met Mrs Gerry, and all her family— Thence Mr. Quincy accompanied me to the Exchange; left me there about 20 minutes in which I read the Letters received by the Mail— My Son George, Captain of the Company of City Guards came in, unwell and exhausted having been all day upon the field. There were, General Lyman told me about 2600 men. Mr Quincy came again and accompanied me with my Sons John and Charles to the Tremont Theatre, where we were received by the manager Mr Pelby: at whose invitation I attended. I found the Governor in the front box. The performances were Wives as they were, and Maids as they are, and the Lady and the Devil. The house is of a very good size—neat and elegant. It was well filled without crowd. It was opened for the first time last Night. The company are generally good, without any very distinguished performer. The Orchestra good; but neither of the plays of this Evening was musical— We left the Theatre about half past ten just before the farce finished. I parted from the Governor, and from Mr Quincy, at the door, and came back to lodge at the Exchange.
26. V. Candle light. Beverly— I. Thorndike’s— Salem— N. Silsbee’s.

list.item: G. W. and C. F. A.

div.p:
George and Charles came and breakfasted with us; and George told me that last Evening, from the time he returned home, until he was put to bed, he was light headed, and continued giving his words of command, as if he had been still upon the field; of which he has no memory or consciousness this morning. He attributes it to the great fatigue of the day; having gone out quite unwell, and fasted the whole day. Coll. Hatch of Attleborough came to say that he was growing old and falling into poverty and would be glad to have a place—any one that I might have it in my power, and feel disposed to give him— He pleaded his revolutionary services, and said he might though he never had claimed a pension. He also alleged that he had been the first mover of the Turnpike roads in this State, and the first petitioner to the Legislature for the Turnpike from Boston to Providence: which he said he had carried through with the aid of Fisher Ames. Mrs Askins was also a claimant. She is the widow of a man who served in the Revolutionary War— She brought with her two newspapers, one containing a narrative of a gallant atchievement of her husband during that war in capturing as Lieutenant of the Lincoln Galley, with twelve men, the Post of Annapolis Royal, in Nova-Scotia, and 150 Men— The other was a paragraph announcing his death, at Alney in the State of Maine, on the 4th of March last, and referring more briefly to the same exploit. She said her husband at one period of his life had been wealthy but in his last days had met with misfortunes, become poor and died of a broken heart— She herself had come to Boston, and to support herself had taken a house and received boarders, but was not successful. Her husband
before his death had petitioned Congress for a pension— Mr Webster had given encouragement to expect that an Act would be passed in his favour— But it had gone over from Session to Session three or four years, and now since the death of her husband she thought herself entitled to obtain, whatever should have been granted to him. I advised her to see Mr Webster again, and also Mr Gorham, now the Member of Congress from the District, and ask their assistance to get the act for her relief through Congress—and promised any aid that it might be in my power with propriety to give— She said her claim amounted to about twenty-three hundred dollars— A man by the name of Slack wrote me a Letter, and afterwards came himself, with a claim for pay, half pay, and clothing as a Soldier in the army, about which I told him he must write to the Secretary of War. Judge Hall came and sat with me about half an hour, conversing chiefly upon politics— At eleven O’Clock I left Boston with my Son John in a Carriage, and passing through Salem, went to Beverly and dined with Mr Israel Thorndike— Mrs Thorndike, Mrs Webster, Edward and Augustus Thorndike, his Sons, Dr Prince, Mr Timothy Pickering, Mr Peabody, Coll. D. L. Pickman, Messrs.Silsbee, Crowninshield, Webster, Everett, Gorham, Dane, Derby, Shepherd, Stevens, and several others were there— We walked before dinner in Mr Thorndike’s garden, and he informed me there was a manufacturing establishment at Chelmsford, now forming their funds, and about to commence their operations. After dinner, we came over to Salem, and take lodgings by invitation at Mr Silsbee’s. Mr Shepherd stopped only a few minutes and returned to Boston— His daughter is here— Dr Barstow and Mr Sprague paid evening visits.
27. V:30. Candle-Light— H. Colman’s, Lynn— Boston.

Morning visit to judge Story. Met Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn at his door. Conversation animated. I then rode with my Son John to Mr H. Colman’s country lodge at Lynn: about five Miles out of Salem. He returned with us. I visited and viewed with him the interior of his own Meeting house, and that of Mr Upham, both of which have been recently built— The method of warming them was alike in both, by a furnace from below, and appears convenient— Mr Upham’s church is elevated upon a basement story, upon the street and rented for three shops. In the same there is a communion table made of Oak, with an inscription on a silver plate found to one side of it, importing that it was of timber first used in building the Church in 1670. and again on the rebuilding in 1716. and was from a tree 180 years old when felled— Mr Colman’s Church is rectangular— Mr Upham’s at the Western side upon the Street semicircular—an inconvenient form for the shape of the pews— I visited Mr Crowninshield and saw his two daughters, and two of his Sons— Mrs Crowninshield was out of town. I also called at Coll Benjamin Pickman’s, and saw him, his wife and two daughters— He is lame from an accident which some months since happened to him, of breaking his leg: and he bears otherwise marks of old age and affliction— I then visited the Athenaeum—the Essex Historical Society’s chamber, and the Marine Society’s Hall—to the curiosities of which there have been few additions, since I was present at the opening of it two years ago— Lastly I visited with Mr Colman, Dr Holyoke, now in his hundredth year. Graduated in and the oldest unstarr’d son of Harvard, in the Catalogue recently published— He has been through this long life a practising physician at Salem, and has always borne a highly respectable character— His health is good, and with the exception in a small degree of hearing, his faculties appear to be unimpaired— I conversed with him upon the atmospherical phenomenon, observed on the 28th of last Month, which he saw, and he said he had at distant intervals, twice before seen luminous appearances, generally resembling that. There were with the doctor, his grandson, a physician of his own name, and a Lady, whom I did not recognize, but who told me she had known me heretofore, as Mrs Carter (Nathanael) of Newbury-Port— I dined at Mr Silbee’s, with his wife and daughter, two brothers, Miss Shepherd, Messrs. Crowninshield, Colman, Dearborn, Derby, Flynt, Miller, Peabody, Peel, Pickering, Sprague, Stevens, Story, Walls, White, and several others— After an old revolutionary claimant Officer, came and told me his story—his name was Brown— In the Evening I returned with John to Boston, and at the Exchange Hotel, found Letters from Mrs Adams, Mr Southard, and others.
28. V. Candlelight— Cambridge— Botanic Garden— Boston— Federal Street Theatre.

list.item: G. W. and C. F. Adams

div.p:
I wrote again an hour by Candle-light, and answered the Letters of Mrs Adams and Mr Southard— My Sons George and Charles came and breakfasted with us— I had morning visitors— Mr Brooks is one of the Sons of Mr Peter C Brooks, who resides at New-York, and comes now to be married to Miss Dehon of this City. Mr English came to speak of his Son George who has returned from the Mediterranean with Commodore Rodgers— Mr Coolidge proposed to me again to fix a day to go with the Directors of the Middlesex Canal upon a party up the Canal; but I told him I should not have time for the present year, and must postpone it.— Bartlett is a ruin—living on from year, and still talks of dying, and publishing books— He said he had one now in the press dedicated to Mr Clay; for which he had been offered 500 dollars but expected to obtain 1200. Mr Thomas Wait the printer came to enquire concerning the publication of Correspondence of the continental Congress during the Revolutionary War, now placed under the direction of Mr Jared Sparks— Mr Wait reminded me of the wish he had heretofore made known to me, of printing this Correspondence, and said it was still entertained by him— Mr Fuller called to make some arrangements for accompanying me, on my visit to the Botanic Garden at Cambridge— Dr Welsh began a Conversation with me concerning my Son George’s health which is infirm: but we were interrupted— My Son Charles went with me to Cambridge— We took up Mr Fuller at his Office, and set him down at the Bank in Cambridge. Then proceeded, and called on Mr Richard Dana and his two Sisters, children of the late Chief Justice Dana, my early friend and patron. I was gratified to find them living in comfort, and even in elegance— My next call was at President Kirkland’s, but he was riding out. Then at Dr. Waterhouse’s. Mrs Waterhouse, Mrs Peck, widow of the late Professor, Dr. Hill and Mr Folsom, who has been the Chargé d’Affaires of our Consulate at Tunis, went with us to the Botanic Garden, where Mr Nuttall attended us over the grounds— The garden is small, and in some decay.
