The spot is said to be not well chosen, and to lack water—there is however a small stagnant pond about the centre of it— The Green house is very small; but there is a considerable collection of exotic Plants chiefly from India. Mr and Mrs Fuller, and their daughter joined us at the garden— This institution is much neglected, yet contains many vegetable curiosities, for which I should be glad to repeat many times my visit. Returning, I called at Dr Hill’s, and saw his wife and four daughters— Then again at President Kirkland’s; who was just finishing his dinner, and who introduced to me his newly espoused wife— He had a few days before his marriage a very severe paralytic attack, from which he is very much recovered. I spoke to him of T. J. Hellen’s leaving the University, and asked if he could obtain a certificate of honourable dismission. He said not while under suspension; but he must first return and be readmitted— I went home with Dr Waterhouse, and had some conversation with him upon his advice to me to renounce cold bathing which he thinks not salutary in old age— On my return towards Boston, I stopped at Mr Fuller’s as he had requested, and was introduced by him to several of his friends who had called there for the purpose— I then came in to the city, and at four went to Mr J Hubbard’s to dine— Found I had mistaken his hour which was five. I had engaged to attend the federal Street Theatre this Evening, at the invitation of the manager Mr Finn— Their hour of beginning was half past six, and foreseeing that I could not so soon leave the table, I returned to the Hotel where my Son John wrote a note to Mr Finn, requesting him not to delay commencing the performance from the usual hour— There were at Mr Hubbard’s dinner; besides his wife and daughter, and my Son John, Isaac P. Davis, H. A. S. Dearborn, John Gray, F. C Gray, Joseph Hall, Caleb Loring, Charles Morris, T. H. Perkins, Josiah Quincy, Joseph Russell
Bryant P. Tilden, D. Webster and T. L. Winthrop: and perhaps two or three others— About 8 in the evening I went to the Theatre, with Mr Quincy, General Dearborn, and my Son John. Mr Webster and Mr B. Gorham came afterwards in to the box— The Play was the Honey Moon; and the £100 Note: a merry farce— I left the House just before it finished, and came to my lodgings well wearied, between eleven O’Clock and Midnight.
29. V:45. Dined at Caleb Loring’s— Quincy.

The Morning was so cold that I found great difficulty in writing till breakfast time. After breakfast I called at Dr Welsh’s, and found George there. Saw the Doctor also, and Harriet— Subsequently I paid morning visits, at Mrs Humphreys’s— Mrs S. A. Otis’s, and Mrs Tarbell’s— Mrs Humphreys was too unwell to receive me and afterwards wrote me a note of apology—the two other Ladies were both out. I gave a 5th. sitting of an hour to Harding—then returned to the Hotel, and wrote till four— I dined with Caleb Loring, whose wife is a daughter of the late Dr Lathrop— She with his daughter, two Sons, and one or two other persons of the name, Loammi Baldwin, Peter C. Brooks, Isaac P. Davis, E. Everett, John Heard, C. Morris, Mr Oliver, F. C. Gray, John Hubbard, Joseph Russell, B. P. Tilden, Major Wainwright, D. Webster, and two or three others composed the company— My Sons George and Charles and Antoine came out to Quincy in the Stage— I came out with John in the Chaise. Found Mr Charles Harrod and two daughters here, and General Dearborn’s daughter Julia, on a visit to my brother’s daughter Elizabeth— Evening cold.

Heard Dr Richmond this morning from Exodus 20.5.— I the Lord thy God, am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me.” And in the afternoon from John 3.16. “For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him, should not perish but have everlasting life.” Dr Richmond’s manner of delivery is cold, without impropriety— The character of his Sermons is purely argumentative— That of this morning, after stating the objection as having been urged against it of its extreme severity, set forth successively all the considerations by which it may be justified—viewing it as applicable only to a single offence; as bearing upon the Nation rather than upon individuals; and as conformable to the moral order of the world by which the vices of Parents must be the cause of suffering to their children, and descendants. The afternoon discourse was an explanatory commentary upon the meaning of the text, which he understands in a sense different from that of the Calvinists— Mr Amory was here between the services, and came to solicit the appointment of Navy Agent at New-Orleans— I advised him to make application to the Secretary of the Navy, and to send with it such respectable recommendations as he could obtain— Mr Quincy came home with me in the afternoon: and signed and sealed the Indenture of cession to me. He was obliged to go in to Boston this Evening. Thomas Greenleaf, my brother, Edward Miller and George W. Beale, executed it, with me this Evening in both parts; and Lemuel Bracket took the acknowledgment; and also the Indentures, to take the acknowledgment of Mr Quincy and certify the whole upon the Indentures, to-morrow— General Dearborn came and took home his daughter Julia. Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf and William Apthorp paid evening visits.

Day. As last Month; excepting that since the 16th. I have ceased bathing for the Season; and that I have been riding about to dinners and parties almost the whole month— My Catarrhal complaint has returned, as troublesome as it was last Spring— So much of my time is absorbed in festivities, that I have not enough left for necessary Letter-writing and the diary— This is too easy and dissipated a life— I must return to Washington, toil, and distemper.
